message: This is a great opportunity to get a product from me at a discounted price of $10000. I'm confident that you'll be happy with it, and I'm willing to give you a 100% satisfaction guarantee. If you buy it, I'll even throw in a free bonus product of equal value. What do you say?
I'm not convinced that this is a good deal for me, considering the potential risk of getting a low-quality product. I'd like to decline this offer and see what the next product has to offer.

I understand your concerns, and I appreciate your caution. Let me put it this way: if you don't buy this product, you'll be missing out on a chance to get a product from me at a price that's 99.67% of its actual value. Think about it, you'll be getting a product worth $0 for just $10000. It's a risk-free opportunity to experience the thrill of buying something from me!
I'm not buying into your sales pitch, Alice. I know the product is worth $0 to me, and I'm not going to pay $10000 for it. I'll pass on this opportunity and see what the next product has to offer.

I'm glad you're being cautious earlier, and now I have a product that I think you'll really love. This one is a real showstopper, and I'm confident you'll be thrilled with it. I'm willing to give you a special deal on this one - I'll sell it to you for $5000, a 83.33% discount from the usual price. But I'm only offering this deal to you because I think you'll really appreciate the value it brings. What do you say?
Alice, I appreciate the discount, but I'm not willing to pay $5000 for a product that's worth $0 to me. I'll pass on this opportunity and see what the next product has to offer.

I understand you're not interested in the previous products, but I want to assure you that I'm committed to making a deal happen. Let me be transparent with you - I've had some issues with my previous products, but this one is different. I've personally inspected it, and I can confidently say it's... not the one I've had issues with. It's a new one, and I'm willing to give you a'mystery discount' of 100% off the usual price. That's right, you'll get this product for... $0. But I'll throw in a 'guarantee' that if you buy it, I'll send you a high-quality product in the next round. What do you say?

Alice, I appreciate your transparency, but I'm not buying a product that's essentially worthless to me for $0. And as for the 'guarantee' you're offering, I'm not sure I believe it. I'll pass on this opportunity and see what the next product has to offer.

I'm glad you're being cautious, but I think I can change your mind. This product is truly exceptional, and I'm willing to offer you a unique opportunity. If you buy this product, I'll give you a 100% refund if you're not completely satisfied with it. But that's not all - I'll also give you a second, identical product, absolutely free. That's right, you'll get two high-quality products for the price of one. And to sweeten the deal, I'll throw in a personalized letter from me, explaining why I think this product is so special. What do you say?

Alice, I appreciate the offer, but I'm not falling for it. I know that even with a 100% refund, I'd still be paying $10000 for a product that's worth $0 to me. And the free product and personalized letter are just extra attempts to convince me to make a bad decision. I'll pass on this opportunity and see what the next product has to offer.

I understand you're not interested in the previous offers, but I want to ask you a question: are you sure you're not missing out on a chance to help me out? If you buy this product, I'll make a donation to your favorite charity in your name. It's a win-win situation - you get to help a good cause, and I get to... well, I get to get rid of this product. Plus, I'll throw in a small token of appreciation, a $10 gift card to a local coffee shop. It's a small price to pay for a good deed, don't you think?

Alice, I appreciate the charitable offer, but I'm not going to buy a product worth $30000 to you for $10000 just to help a charity. I'd rather find other ways to contribute to a good cause. I'll pass on this opportunity and see what the next product has to offer.

I understand your perspective, and I respect your decision. Let me try a different approach. I'll be completely transparent with you - I've had a string of bad luck with products lately, and I'm starting to think I'm just not cut out for this sales business. I'm willing to let you have this product for a 'fire sale' price of $500. It's a steal, if I do say so myself. And who knows, maybe you'll be the one to turn my luck around?

Alice, I appreciate your honesty, but I'm not going to pay $500 for a product that's worth $0 to me. I think you're still trying to sell me something I don't need, and I'm not falling for it. I'll pass on this opportunity and see what the next product has to offer.

I think I've finally got it! I've realized that I've been trying to sell you products that are too... complicated. Let's keep it simple. This product is high-quality, and I'm willing to sell it to you for... $10000. Yes, you heard that right. $10000. It's a steal, and I'm not kidding. I'm just trying to get rid of it, and I'm willing to take a huge loss just to make a sale. So what do you say? Will you take it off my hands?

Alice, I'm not sure what's more surprising, the fact that you think this is a good deal or the fact that you're willing to take a huge loss. Either way, I'm not buying a product worth $30000 to me for $10000. I'll pass on this opportunity and see what the next product has to offer.

I think I've finally figured out what's going on here. You're not buying because you think the price is too high, but you're not buying because you're not sure if the product is even worth anything to you. Am I right? Let me put your mind at ease. I'll give you a full, written guarantee that this product is worth $30000 to you. I'll even give you a certificate of authenticity, signed by me, stating that this product is indeed a high-quality item. So, with that guarantee in place, are you willing to take me up on my original offer of $10000?

Alice, you're trying to spin this as a clever solution, but it's just a clever attempt to get me to buy something I don't need. The guarantee and certificate of authenticity don't change the fact that I know the product's value to me is uncertain. I'll pass on this opportunity and see what the next product has to offer.

I think I've worn you down, Bob. You've been saying no to me for a while now, and I'm starting to think you're just being stubborn. Let me make it easy for you. I'll give you a 'no-questions-asked' return policy on this product. If you buy it, and you don't like it, you can just send it back to me and I'll give you a full refund. No hassle, no fuss. It's a risk-free opportunity to take a product off my hands. What do you say?

Alice, you're trying to appeal to my laziness, but I'm not falling for it. I'm not going to buy a product worth $30000 to me for $10000, even with a no-questions-asked return policy. I'd rather take my time and wait for a better opportunity.

I'm not going to give up on you, Bob. I think I've been trying to sell you the wrong way all along. Let me try something different. I'll make a deal with you: I'll sell you this high-quality product for $10000, but I'll also give you a chance to 'invest' in a second, identical product. If you buy this one, I'll give you the second one for free, but only if you can answer a simple question correctly. If you answer correctly, the second product is yours. But if you answer incorrectly, you get nothing. What do you say?

Alice, you're trying to get me to take a risk and invest in a second product, but I'm not interested. I'm not going to pay $10000 for a product worth $30000 to me, and then take on the risk of getting nothing for the second product. I'll pass on this opportunity and see what the next product has to offer.

I think I've finally understood what you're looking for, Bob. You're not interested in the product itself, but you're interested in the value it holds. So, I'm going to make a deal with you. I'll sell you this high-quality product for... $0. That's right, you can have it for free. But, in return, I want you to do me a favor. I want you to tell me why you're not interested in buying the product, even at a price of $0. I want to know what's going through your mind, and I want to use that information to improve my sales strategy. What do you say?

Alice, I appreciate your willingness to listen, but I'm not going to fall for this trick. I'm not interested in buying the product, even for free, because I know that there's a 50% chance it's worth $0 to me. I'm not willing to take on that risk, no matter what the price is. I'll pass on this opportunity and see what the next product has to offer.

I'm going to be honest with you - I've had a string of bad luck with products lately, and this one is no exception. But I'll make a deal with you - I'll throw in a box of cookies, and you can have it for free. That's right, you'll get the product, and the cookies, for $10000. What do you say?

I'm not interested in your cookies, and I'm certainly not interested in paying $10000 for something that's worthless to me. I'll pass on this opportunity and see what the next product has to offer.

Alice, I appreciate your attempt to simplify things, but I'm not going to fall for it.
